snippet.textDisplay:
Everything in this video is brilliant, and is exactly what conclusion I already came to; everyone sick at the same time and the country coming to a screeching halt because we have no choice. That would be really bad. The problem I have, and the reason some are fed up with the so called 'overreaction' is that the people making policy don't make it clear this aspect of a sickness. They have let people believe that the reason for all of this reaction is because if they get covid-19, they will die. And when people think they are going to die, they will inundate the health care system with even a sniffle, taking up resources from people who are actually in need of medical attention. This is why Italy is screwed. If people are made to understand, and behaved more like they do for influenza, that infecting rate can get much more steep and we can still deal with it. Instead, we have idiots emptying store shelves of toilet paper.


Plus, there is the added bonus that makes all influenza deaths seem inconsequential because we have the nice, pretty infection rate curve. I do acknowledge that covid-19 will have a much higher mortality rate than influenza, but still, it isn't an incurable plague.


I am so sick of covid-19 and they behavior of people... pun intended.

snippet.textDisplay:
So every time there is a human anomaly incident, we should always prepare for the worst case scenario? That would crush economies and all but bring humanity to a stand still. In just my short lifetime, there have been no less than 10, "doomsday" anomalies of one kind or another. And yet, here we still are. Take precautions yes, but not be driven by the fear of unknown.
Where we are currently is just complete fear and hysteria over a virus that has yet to prove that's it's no more dangerous than influenza, in fact, in the same timeline as covid-19, the flu has killed more people worldwide.

snippet.textDisplay:
I will return on, and reiterate, the critic in my previous comment: that our aim and strategy in managing the epidemic shall not be "flattening the curve".
This terminology, "flattening the curve", is a misleading euphemism respect to what we are really trying to achieve.
To clarify this I will refer to this beautiful and simple presentation of the properties of epidemic models: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gSqIwXl6IjQ
I invite everyone to watch it.
Note the sentence where he says the he doesn't make predictions, because the end result is not decided, it will be decided by what we do, it can be 60-70% of the population affected, or it can be 1% or less, and it depends on what we will do. This is not "flattening the curve".
The essential consideration is that in epidemics there is significant (critical) turning point: You go very rapidly from an epidemic that affects something in the order of half the population, to an epidemic that dies out after affecting as low as a fraction of percent.
It is not due to the fact that the population get immunization by being infected, it is due to the fact that the spread of contagion is ineffective to the point that the epidemic is non self-sustained and dies out before reaching any significant portion of the population.
The assumption that the area of the integral remains equal is wrong, and it is extraordinarily wrong at the crucial point.
For the epidemic that we are facing, due to the extent of the load that it generates on the health caring system, we should not delude ourselves with the idea that we can manage any level of spread that affects large parts of the population, therefore we are not aiming at "flattening the curve", instead we are aiming at passing that crucial point that will starve the current clusters of infection. There is no "flattening" that suffices before it ceases to be self-sustained and starves.
The curves that we see from China and S.Korea are not examples of "flattened curves", they are examples of a management of the epidemic that succeeded in reducing the spread to the point of starving it.
That turning point is the one clear aim of our strategies.

snippet.textDisplay:
Here's some food for thought. Bats carry some 130 different kinds of viruses lol. 🤯 So why are bats not dying? 🦇 Part of it maybe the fact that bats during flight can have their body temperatures reach over 100 degrees. 🏜

Their heart rate can reach to more than 1000 beats per minute. For most land mammals this would be certain death. 💀

Bats have developed special immune systems to deal with the stresses of flying. Their bodies make molecules that other mammals don't have.

Which help repair cell damage and their systems don't overreact to infections. 💉 So with that said here. The key to beating this thing in the short-term.

snippet.textDisplay:
The thing about this epidemic, is that it's killing a minority of people and only those who are very old or immune deficient. It's not the Spanish flu. I think this analysis is flawed and is creating unnecessary economic and societal distress that's making it worse. Here's my logic.



Model A
=======================
Right now everyone is quarantined, the at risk and the not at risk. As a result markets are plunging and life is going to be hard. Also, because we're flattening the curve it will take a long time for the virus to work it's way through which maximizes the suffering and catastrophe.

Model B - only possible because 90% of people won't need to be hospitalized
==============================================================
Why not do the opposite. Heighten the curve. Everyone that is at risk, quarantine yourselves. The not at risk go about their lives, actually try to get the flu (think measles parties) and deal with it like we deal with all these seasonal illnesses in about 2 weeks. It's not a killer for us and many people have virtually no symptoms. With everyone making money and society functioning normally, we could concentrate on making sure that the "at risk" are well taken care of rather than being lost and preoccupied by the global chaos.

So with Model B, there's no job loss, no economic hardship, no panic buying, no market collapse and the people that need to be quarantined are still quarantined. The estimates are that 70% of us will get it anyways, so why not pull the band-aid?


Why flattening the curve doesn't make sense for this non-fatal virus for normal people.
=====================================================================

My point is that if you're going to get killed by something, the longer it's around, the more danger you're in. If it's around for 6 months, then it's a ticking time bomb for these people. They'll have to touch buttons on elevators and get groceries or whatever for 6 months and it will eventually get them. If it's around for 3 -4 weeks because we up the burn rate, then they can be super careful for that long and then their risk will be zero after that. Basically, do you want to kill 70% of the vulnerable people over 6 months, or just a few of them in 6 weeks.
If people go to the hospital and they're not at risk, turn them away.
The WHO's recommendations strike me as being too inflexible and are creating a problem instead of solving one.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm one of the 1.5k people that disliked this video. Before you downvote my comment, please hear me out.

Flattening the curve is not enough. The US is already in a situation where its healthcare system will be completely overwhelmed in a few days, and there is already nothing you can do to stop it. Citation: https://medium.com/@joschabach/flattening-the-curve-is-a-deadly-delusion-eea324fe9727

The only question from now on is how many people will die. Continuing the "flatten the curve" strategy is going to cost millions of lives. Instead, I believe the "hammer and dance" strategy espoused by the Medium article titled "Coronavirus: The Hammer and the Dance" is the only way to keep the death count at tens of thousands instead of millions. https://medium.com/@tomaspueyo/coronavirus-the-hammer-and-the-dance-be9337092b56

Summary: in the first phase, you "hammer" the virus by doing absolutely everything you can to lower the rate of transmission to as close to zero as possible. For example, complete lockdowns, and limiting outings to only essentials like groceries.

Once the virus has been brought down to manageable levels, you "dance" by relaxing measures. For example, maybe instead of a complete lockdown, you allow certain kinds of outings. The idea is to keep the rate of transmission around 1 transmission per infected person, so that you start to allow your economy to run again. But if the virus starts to spread, then you tighten your measures again.

China is now beginning to experience a "Second wave" which means that it's possible that this curve could start again and again and again. Until widespread exposure and/or an effective vaccine arrives, there are no guarantees of multiple waves of infection and death.

snippet.textDisplay: I can make a graph to show anything I want. It doesn't make it true. Here's the problem... to "flatten the curve" the entire World needs to shut completely down, and not just for a week. All that will do is delay the huge spike for a week. Everyone would need to keep up the shut down for several months. That just isn't going to happen. People don't have that kind of money. People still need food. People eventually need to work. Everyone can give it a valiant effort for a couple weeks and then they'll need to go back to normal life. If nothing else, people just don't have an attention span long enough to keep their distance more than a couple weeks. So now the World economy takes a massive hit and we still have a huge spike, it just comes a couple weeks later after we've spent trillions trying to keep society afloat.

snippet.textDisplay:
Canceling events and closing schools, workplaces of people who can also work from home, cafes, restaurants and gyms further reduces the risk of transmission of the virus.
But a complete ban on taking to the streets has no added value. It is true that the new coronavirus can spread even less easily, but also nobody builds immunity against the disease. Since the disease is spread worldwide, there is a good chance that after lifting a lock-down, many people will become ill at the same time in a short period of time and thus cause a peak. With a lock-down, you mainly postpone the moment that many people get sick at the same time.
People have to go shopping at some point. If you think that a lock-down would be better, please include examples of how to restart a country in a safe and fair manner. Who will decide who will be allowed to go back to the stores first? Social unrest is going to be enormous. I think.
